awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Synthesis of Thiolated Carboranes for Self-Assembled Monolayers on a Dy-doped CdO Surface
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to synthesize thiolated carboranes, organic molecules that are stable in water and extreme heat. These organic molecules will be attached to a plasmonic active material - cadmium oxide doped with dysprosium (CdO:Dy) - to protect it from being soluble in water and acidic solutions. CdO:Dy was recently reported as the first semiconductor that can host surface plasmons in the mid-infrared region as well as being an ideal material for mid-infrared biosensor chips. Investigation regarding whether or not the infrared vibration of these organic molecules can be detected when attached on CdO:Dy using Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) spectrometry will be performed in addition to exploring the possibility of using CdO:Dy as a biosensor chip. This project will be conducted at Zhejiang University in China with Professor Simon Duttwyler, an expert in carboranes synthesis. This work will lead to development of a sensitive mid-IR biosensor that can be used in drug discovery and also in small molecule detection for scientific research.

A recently reported plasmonic active material, dysprosium doped cadmium oxide (CdO:Dy) possesses extreme peak of mobility and tunable carrier concentration giving rise to Surface Plasmon Resonance across the mid-IR range. Though CdO:Dy is an ideal mid-IR material for a biosensor due to its spectrally narrow and sharp plasmonic band, its solubility in water and instability in acidic solution pose many challenges experimentally. To overcome these obstacles, an objective of this EAPSI project aims to synthesize extremely hydrophobic and thermally stable molecules, thiolated carboranes, that will not only protect CdO substrate from (acidic) solutions, but also permit subsequent detection of these molecules through Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) spectroscopy; this will also facilitate the simultaneous investigation of potentially using CdO:Dy as a biosensor. Furthermore, thiolated carboranes will be deposited on CdO:Dy substrate using self-assembled monolayer, furthering the fundamental understanding of surface chemistry between Dy-doped CdO surface and organic molecules.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

por.por_cntn:
My EAPSI research focused on synthesizing new thiolated carboranes that are stable in water and heat. These molecules will be used as a protective layer for dysprosium doped cadmium oxide (CdO:Dy) film that is soluble in water. CdO:Dy was recently reported as the first semiconductor that can host surface plasmons in the mid-infrared region and has potential to be utilized as a mid-IR biosensor. The advantages of attaching carborane on a CdO surface is that it has potential to protect CdO surface from water and carborane has an IR band at 2550 cm-1, which can be used for detection when using surface plasmon resonance. To explore this theory, three different carboranes – [CB11H12S]-, [CB11H12]- Cysteine Cation and [CB11H12]- Methyl Methionate Cation – were successfully synthesized during the EAPSI period in Dr. Simon Duttwyler’s lab at Zhejiang University, China. Furthermore, optimal conditions for a monolayer solution deposition on CdO was explored. To determine if the carborane attaches to the CdO surface, several surface characterization methods such as XPS, AFM and Water Contact Angle were employed. Preliminary results suggest the attachment of carborane on the CdO surface, although the surface coverage seems to be poor. Ideal conditions for monolayer deposition are still under investigation and will be followed by the exploration of the coupling of surface plasmon and molecular vibration of carborane.

The EAPSI fellowship program allowed me to experience a research environment very different from what I am used to in my own lab. I learned to adapt and communicate proficiently with new group members as well as gaining a lifetime of friendships with some of the group members. This program introduced me to a new skillset while advancing the overall goal of my current thesis. Due to the nature of the project, infusing material science, organic and analytical chemistry, many research ideas beyond the proposed project were discussed with the host professor as well as other professors from various departments. I also had the opportunity to attend the IMEBORON 16 conference in Hong Kong during my time in China and gained began an additional collaborative effort with a professor from UCLA.

Furthermore, Dr. Simon Duttwyler is scheduled to give a seminar at my university (NCSU) in March 2018 and we will be discussing new research ideas that will ensure the continuation of our collaboration.

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2018
Modified by: Hniang Khamh
